thread.title: CBA takes team title at Shore Coaches Championship
thread.title_full: CBA takes team title at Shore Coaches Championship

author: app.com
title: CBA takes team title at Shore Coaches Championship
text:
MORE HOLMDEL Watch out, cross country world.
The Christian Brothers Academy Colts are coming at you.
Again.
"Last year's team was deep, but this year's team is 10 times deeper," said CBA junior star Noah Yuro after leading his Colts to yet another team title yesterday, in the rainy, cold, windswept conditions that made the annual New Balance Shore Coaches Invitational Meet at Holmdel Park a true test of grit and guts.
Well, "10 times deeper" may be a slight exaggeration but there are no doubts that the 2015 edition of the CBA XC team is a force to be reckoned with on the state, regional and national levels. Almost all national polls at the moment have the Colts ranked number one.
A week ago, Coach Tom Heath's runners scored a decisive team victory over other Eastern powers at the Bowdoin Classic Meet in Wappingers Falls, N.Y. Heath kept most of his top racers on the sidelines yesterday at Holmdel Park - keeping them fresh for the big Manhattan College Invitational next Saturday at Van Cortandt Park in New York - but the Colts had more than enough talent to win their Boys Varsity A-1 division race
by a huge margin.
Haddon Township's Owen Long (16:20), Eastern Regional's Nicholas Pschunder (16:23) and Hillsborough's Brandon Tubby (16:38) took the 1-2-3 individual medals in this one, but the CBA pack was hard on their heels over the 5,000-meter course that was made far more
difficult than usual by the brutal conditions.
Yuro claimed fourth in 16:38) and the entire CBA scoring group crossed the line within 29 seconds - with Joe Boyle seventh (16:48), Genaro Anzalone 10th (1:58), Chris Trigani 11th (17:01) and Matthew Cavallaro 14th (16:58.) All are juniors.
That gave CBA a low-low 39-point total, and a total team time of 1:24:32 and an average of 16:54.
Southern Regional, led by sophomore Evan Adanatzian (ninth in 16:38), was a distant runner-up in the team race with 111 points, a 1:27:18 total and a 17:27.60 average.
"We wanted to kind of hang back in the pack the first mile, then move up, just as usual," said Yuro. "I'm just hoping I make our team running the Manhattan meet."
Two other Shore squads ran off with team titles in the mega-event that listed 27 races that ran from 9 a.m. to past 5 p.m.
Red Bank Catholic claimed the girls Varsity D division title with 55 points and a 1:45.39 total, for a 21:07.20 average.
The Caseys did it with sophomore Caitlin O'Hare fifth (20:36), senor Louisa Guminski 10th (21:07), sophomore Emily Dunn 11th (21:09) and juniors Melanie Cronk 17th (21:23) and Michelle O'Malley 18th (21:24.) River Dell's 97 points ranked a distant second to the Caseys.
Mater Dei Prep took the Boys Varsity F title with 54 points on a 1:33:10 total and 18:39 average.
Powering the Seraphs were John Spinelli in fifth (17:49), Justin Vidal 10th (18:30), Pat Osborn 11th (18:31), Nick Roditis 14th (18:47) and Steven Alegretta 30th (19:33), running a strong second in the Girls C event was Rumson-Fair Haven, with 98 points (20 back of winning Summit) as Emily Wellman snared sixth (20:05), Rebecca Ley 17th (20:39), Sarah Nelson 20th (20:52), Julia Tambaro 26th (21:10) and Olivia Rehder 29th (21:24.)
Only power-packed Voorhees, running with its top unit, outranked CBA in boys over-all results. Taking the Varsity C title, on a low 22 score, Voorhees ran a total 1:23:22 for a 16:40.4 average.
Tim Bason, West Windsor-Plainsboro South, was quickest of all boys in the meet with his Varsity B win in 15:58 over Toms River North's J.P. Flavin (16:14.) Varsity B winner Ridge was the fastest of all girls squads with a 1:39:43 total and 19:56.50 average. Fastest over-all girl was Mainland Regional's Alyssa Aldridge (18:20.)
